text.text: An EPA Regional staff member and a community organizer for environmental justice are working together to convene and activate a new group of community members in a rural county with EJ issues. They decide, based on their goals and activity requirements, to do the following activities:
Chapters 1 and 2 - accomplished through planning the workshops. Chapter 3-All; Chapter 4- none, since community workshops also need to fit in emergency preparedness. Chapter 5- All.

A local environmental education and advocacy organization is leading the development of a watershed resilience plan. They decide, based on their goals and activity requirements, to do the following activities:

Chapter 1- project plan; Chapter 2- none, organizations leading this have strong community connections already; Chapter 3- all, Chapter 4- none, too technical and time consuming for the project team; Chapter 5- all.

A county emergency manager is tasked with leading a committee to update the county's Hazard Mitigation Plan. The previous plan has plenty on natural hazards but hasn't incorporated lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic. The committee decides, based on their goals and activity requirement, to do the following activities:

Chapter 1- make a project plan; Chapter 2- originally decided it was too time-consuming, changed their mind after they started planning for community workshops; Chapter 3- Data on hazards and equity, social vulnerability assessment; Chapter 4- All; Chapter 5- activity brainstorming
